commentBody: Deadline showed up late in yesterday's comments. Here is a link to her post. Please come back here to reply to her! https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/4b3gnd?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share
Saw the puzzle creator. Gave it 10 minutes, made a nice dent below.  But this is just gonna have to wait til I'm at my best.  Too tough right now.
Just happen to be reading both Gravity‚Äôs Rainbow and a bit of FICHTE right now, so that helped. (Don‚Äôt ask me to elaborate on either.)

When I call my optometrist, I use my eye phone.

(He's in my contacts.)

Caitlin writes:
...DIESEL HYBRID. They do exist, mostly outside the United States, and many trains use electric and diesel power.

Caitlin,
Virtually all U.S. "diesel" locomotives are diesel-electric: they have diesel engines that drive electric motors. The diesel engine is not connected to the drive wheels. Locomotives in the NYC metro area that use diesel and electric power are not hybrids: they power their electric motors from third rail or overhead wire in and near Penn Station and Grand Central, and turn on their diesel engines to power the motors when they are in non-electrified territory.
So many clues with question marks? Are ae are getting our Halloween trick early?
Thought the northeast corner was a bit too much

OK, what have you done with the *real* Sam Ezersky? üòÄ Don't get me wrong, this was not easy *at all*: but I didn't have to desperately scour the grid for anything to answer. The clues were brilliant, though; this made for a perfect Saturday puzzle. Thank you Sam (for this and for doing the Spelling Bee too, of course).

Yes. 

Y E S.

Thank you, Saturday gods, for this gift of a Sam E. puzzle. 

I woke up in the middle of the night (to find my husband watching TV‚Äîcollege football is a demanding love when the Friday night game comes at 4am), saw that the puzzle had just dropped, and thought, ‚ÄúHuh, why not.‚Äù And then‚Äîbliss. What a fantastic treat. 

Yes.

This felt like a good old fashioned Saturday to me.  I bogged down about halfway through, and had to grind out the puzzle.  I tried ore instead of ROE and led instead of LCD, which made the NE harder than it should have been.  Finally giving in to my initial impulse to enter CHOCULA got me straightened out.  I struggled in the SE because I had beerhall instead of BRAUHAUS. Even though I knew the answer should be in German, the B, H, and second A all fit so I clung to it like a drowning man to a life preserver.

What really saved me was knowing LAMARJACKSON and TYRONE Slothrop.  I knew reading Gravity‚Äôs Rainbow way back when would come in handy some day.  

Anyway lots of devious clues and fun answers made this one a winner in my book
A very nice puzzle. Lots of fun answers with great clues. Thanks, Sam! Y‚Äôall have a wonderful fall Saturday! It‚Äôs gonna be gorgeous here in AVL this weekend! üçÅüçÇ

It‚Äôs a Sam Ezersky puzzle, the perfect antidote to a (relatively) easy Friday. Proud to say it‚Äôs the first Ezersky puzzle I solved in one night without having to sleep on it. But by no means a walk in the park.
I thought the broey and soapy combo was, to use bridge slang, throwing a loser on a loser.  A weak link on a long bra chain of solid satisfying Saturday puzzles from Sam.

I am pretty sure that was the hardest puzzle I've ever done.

At least I had the most trouble with it.  Over two hours, which harkens back to my solving days of yore.

It took me forever to establish a beachhead, to find a section with several squares filled in that I trusted.

Then I would occasionally get a flash (FROMEARTOEAR, LAMARJACKSON) and thought that would untangle it all.  It didn't.

I don't know how many errors I tore out.
Certainly my fastest ever Ezersky, by a margin of several hours.

Nothing to add to the comments but "Whew! What a workout!"

Thanks, Sam (I think).
Tough one.

Oh dang, this was hard! I enjoyed it though, even if in the end I broke down and looked up some stuff. Having spent over 30 minutes on the solve I was missing very little but no longer making progress so I looked to Google for help.

I've read "The Great Gatsby", but the title character is the only one whose name I remember. With __M there for some reason I went for saM, which wreaked havoc in that corner. I googled TOM in a moment of desperation. 

I've seen SCROD here before, I think, but I didn't remember it today so I looked it up, too.

I was stumped by the P of P TRAP. I know the thing of course, but not its English name. In Polish it's called "syfon" (your "siphon"). Why P trap if it's U-shaped?

I looked up the first two letters of TYRONE, too.

Other than that, it was an enjoyable, clean solve.

BRAUHAUS went through so many transformations ü§£. I started with beer hall (the names of beers in the clue were German but with the English "a", so I thought the answer would be an English word), then changed that to brew hall, after that came brauhall (bear with me), and then I finally arrived at the correct answer. What a ride ü§™

Some arcana, like PETER IV and LAMAR JACKSON, I relied on crosses for.

Now to read the other comments. I bet I'll learn this was a Wednesday, at best toüòÇü•≤

this bronco kicked my derriere from here to...sunday?
finally managed to break it after an hour and a bit.
14D almost made my coffee come out my nose.  top 5 clue of the year, imo.
i must say im a bit jealous of all you veteran fanboys/girls who see the puzzle creators names and immediately know not only how to gird yourselves for whats to come but also board shuttles for trips down memory lane.
"i was doing my third sam ezersky puzzle back in aught 9 when i got my first bank foreclosure notice....ah, those were the days...", e.g.

Tough one with a few really nice misdirections. I had ORE for ROE and NO TRASH instead of NO TRACE. Slow start, but enough in there for me to get the sole going. Never having been to Rochester, I did not know that it was north of Buffalo. 61D made my day, though. Masterful clue. What way to underline the puzzle.

This was hard! 20 min over my average. I had ore, then fry then roe.  
Easy for me: slam bid (Mom was a contract bridge maven), and No Trace since I'm a camper.  
There were so many clues I changed several times.  
But fun! No filler claws except ante, but it was matched with anti!

Wow, so cool to see Lamar make the NYT Crossword, being a Baltimore boy and a huge and disappointed Ravens fan. His achievement is amazing. And we all hope he gets better, Sam. BTW, the puzzle was very Saturday worthy. Thanks for a complex but enjoyable solve!

I liked this one. Solved pretty quickly for a Saturday.  For me, it was one of those that seems hard at first, but somehow all of my wild guesses turned out to be correct. For example, I entered LPRECORD in 13D, hoping it would be wrong because it sounds so awkward, but it was right.  

For a minute, I wondered if I'd fallen asleep and was having a lucid dream (which is when you realize you're dreaming while still asleep and that therefore, anything you can think of is possible.) For example, you can fly, walk through walls, play any song on the piano. On stage and forgot your lines? No problem. It's a dream, so your lines can be whatever comes out of your mouth. Doing a tough Saturday crossword? No worries. It's a dream, so all of your guesses will be the correct answers!

The dream ended when I got to Prince Rogers Nelson (RIP) because I wanted the answer to be something involving "The Artist," but I couldn't make that fit.

And now I have a story about 29A. When I was little, my brother and I decided it would be fun to tear up all of our picture books. I started with just pulling on the thread holding the binding together, but he got bored with that and started ripping pages. All of a sudden, we looked up and there was our babysitter, Mrs. Carson, standing in the doorway with her hands on her cheeks (a la "The Scream"), whispering, "Oh my STARS." She's the only person I've ever heard use that expression, and I'll never forget it.

I really struggled with this one. Ready to give up, I clicked the ‚Äúinfo‚Äù button and saw the byline: SAM EZERSKY. Big sigh. No wonder!  

Unwilling to let that dastardly Spelling Bee-er get the best of me (AGAIN), I went back to the puzzle and persevered. Did I resort to a couple of Google consults? Yes, of course. But did I ultimately finish with no reveals? You bet I did. HA! This Queen Bee is not afraid of you, Sam. (Much.)
To show how far in the weeds I was on this one, at one point I had "deuSELectRIc" for 35A.

I don't think anybody's mentioned one of my favorites yet:

I thought FALSECUT  for [Deck Deception] was breathtaking.  I don't know how long I stared at those eight squares with different letters and a all those positions at different times.

heres a question - that came to me while watching last nights mariners-tigers game (NO SPOILERS!) and marveling how great pitchers dont have the first clue how to hit - for seasoned crossword solvers who also create grids:

is every creative puzzle builder a formidable puzzle solver?
in other words:  can you be really good at the former and not so good at the latter?

With the top half filled and the bottom half blank, I fell asleep thinking I would never crack it. When my wire-haired fox terrier Oliver had to go out at 1am, very unusual for him, I tried again. Thanks to Ollie, I live to fight another day. Finally noticed it was a Sam E puzzle. OK, now I don‚Äôt feel so bad.

Thought it was gonna be easy but turned out tough, enjoyably so though. 
Thank God Count Chocula didn‚Äôt make it to UK ü§¢ ‚Ä¶healthy way to start the day kids! 
As for ANTE, it features so often in the NYT crossword, do the compilers have a collective gambling problem??!
Really well constructed, fair puzzle. No naticks, good clean cluing! A shining example of crossword construction that started our day off on the right foot.
Last I checked, Android phone cameras snap with a tap as well. Device agnostic but still...
Made it about 90% through before I cheated and moved on with my day. Happy Friday!
In the past I found a lot of Ezersky's crosswords pedantic and self-indulgent but I think this one is peachier than those and a fair challenge. Thanks

Sports figures, pedantic flexes about dead monarchs of dead monarchies, and BROEY?

OH JOY.

Nnnnnnot my favorite puzzle.

Oof, that was hard. But it was an Ezersky, so of course. I had to fight for at least 95% of the grid, nothing came easily at all. 

I vaguely remember the sculpture pictured as I lived near Salisbury for a long time, but not the context. Clearly it didn‚Äôt grab my attention. Fantastic Christmas market in the cloisters every year though.

Very on-brand for Ezersky.

Should have waited for my morning coffee. But the adrenaline from that Mariners win was still surging! Can‚Äôt wait to have our Canadian friends back in town.

I let out a little yelp when I saw Sam's name up top.  My (previously) sleeping husband said, "Are you ok?".

More than ok, it's a Sam Ezersky puzzle!

Great cluing all around, and the SE gave me the workout I wanted.

BeerHAll to BRewHAll and finally to BRAUHAUS.

TUVoLU and the unknown A_YA gave me LoMAn JACKSON at first, which seemed fine, but a nagging sense that the country name didn't look right made me change it to TUVALU.  LAMAn?  Could be, but think again!  Mental alphabet run yielded LAMAR.  That's better!  It even sounded familiar.  

Crossed my fingers and handed in my paper.

I'm so glad to see all the positive comments today! I find it a little depressing when lots of people complain eg it's not "Thursday" enough. 

However, I couldn't solve some of this, too much really. The sport, the names, SCROD, CHOCULA, playing cards. 

I find some crosswords easier and some harder quite  unconnected to the day of the week. I mostly enjoy them all.
Was ONE NAME away from completing this puzzle.  Finally the light came on -- just WATT was needed.

With three potential Naticks in the SE, and another at 27D/39A, I was sure there was no way I was going to complete this puzzle without help. After a lot of walking away and returning, the crosses finally did their work.

Having said that, this puzzle was a total drag for me. Obscure names (Fichte? Peter IV?) made it a complete slog. 

Probably the only clue I liked  was  the misdirect at 19A, when I finally got rid of "ore" and realized that it referred to fish. That allowed me to fill in what jumped out right away, but didn't fit, i.e. CHOCULA.  

Sam Ezersky may have 22 Saturday puzzles to his credit, but I can't remember having solved any of them with enjoyment or a great sense of accomplishment. Just my two cents'.
With NO BRA DAY on Thursday and ‚ÄúLongest bra chain‚Äù today, it‚Äôs been Bra Trivia week at the Times crossword.

Is CHOCULA a thing? I‚Äôm missing something, I know.  Some play on Dracula I‚Äôm sure. Please explain!
Nice puzzle‚Äîquite a challenge for me.

I started the day (somewhat) within striking distance of a one year streak (sitting at 329). I saw Sam Ezersky‚Äôs byline. At first I groaned. He‚Äôs bested me before. But 
I buckled down. Determined to keep the streak going. Finally, heard the ‚ÄúSan Jose Strut‚Äù after putting in the ‚ÄúM‚Äù in ‚ÄúIPHONE CAMERA‚Äù and even finished 6 minutes under my average. Not to count my chickens yet, but 330 down, 35 to go (or is it 36 since the streak started during a leap year?)
First time in ages I had to resort to google...I was surprised an Iberian king had an English name...and I just did not know that quarterback..just 2 of my trouble spots....

13 debut answers in this one (an appropriate number). And more than a couple that I was NEVER going to get just from the clues. Cheated more than a bit to manage to get through this one. A bit frustrating but in the end an enjoyable workout. One answer history search today was for various strings of letters in our constructors surname. Some of them didn't go anywhere. Probably the longest answer for any of the sequences was: octobERSKY That was an answer in one puzzle - a Saturday from January 4, 2020 by Adam Aaronson. That one had... eleven answers that never appeared in any other puzzle. That's... unusual. Some of those: HAMBURGLAR ABOSYSTEM CLAPOMETER LIKEBUTTON ALLABOUTME YESSIREEBOB BEGUILING WORLDWARIII Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/4/2020&g=17&d=A I'll return now to my home planet. ...

I had BRAtHAUS, and I liked it, and like so many things we become attached to but are bad for us, I clung to it for way too long.

I learned about 7-down at about age eleven when I heard an off-color joke about a question asked of a Boston cab driver.
One could go to the BIERHAUS but that won‚Äôt solve the puzzle. On the plus side you can drink away the puzzlement. But it‚Äôs early here. Great solve. Thank you.

19A. Smelt can be a type of small silvery fish, so technically, they can be ‚ÄúROE,‚Äù nothing to do with ‚ÄúORE.‚Äù I wish the official NYTs person who writes up explanations and hints for tricky clues did more research/ was more technically accurate.

Solved this unaided, but took me 50 minutes. An excellent, challenging puzzle, marred only by the horrid BROEY. This one felt like a Saturday puzzle of old to me, and solving it left me with a genuine sense of satisfaction.

FICHTE and TYRONE (as clued) were unknowns, but fortunately TUVALU and CHOCULA were not.

Would love to see more Saturday puzzles on this level. Thank you Mr. Ezersky.

Wow, this was great.

Very tough, took me almost ten minutes longer than my Saturday average, but worth it. 

I really, really wanted CHOCULA, but I had too many mistakes in that section to allow it--fry instead of ROE, elbow instead of PTRAP--so the Count had to wait.

I also started out with BierHAll, then BierHAUS, before I could get that one and get a toehold in the bottom right.

Challenges like this, and time to do them, are what Saturdays are for, right?
Just brutal.

Just Sam being Sam.

Freshness, remarkable freshness, with 13 NYT answer debuts, including all three answers of the bottom stack and two of the three in the top stack.  

Junklessness, a grid scrubbed to the bone.  It‚Äôs easy to take this for granted with Sam, because it‚Äôs a feature of all his puzzles.  But no ‚Äì it is ridiculously hard to pull this off even once, and I will never take it for granted.

Sterling original clues never seen before in the major crossword outlets for common answers, such as [React to something moving, say], for CRY, and [Job done on one‚Äôs hands and feet?] for MANIPEDI.

Loveliness in answer: FALSE CUT, NO TRACE, BRAUHAUS, BROEY, MIFFS.

But most importantly, how was the solve?  For me, fully engaging, rife with brain-happifying riddles to crack, leaving me with an ‚ÄúAHH, now *that* was a crossword‚Äù feeling.

Once again, the art and science of crosswords showcased by you, Sam.  You being you.  Thank you for another jewel!

Sam bested me. The crossing of Hegel‚Äôs philosopher and the Iberian king was an utter natick for me. I looked up the king, and then the QB, and still couldn‚Äôt finish it. So I hit autocheck, and it turned out that uTRAP was my only error. Limped over the finish line. That‚Äôs okay, it‚Äôs Saturday. Yeesh though. Going to have to walk that one off.

This felt hard but somehow I vibed with it and came in under 10min. I immediately intuited ‚Äúhow to grin‚Äù and was saying (unironically) OH JOY not too long after. Only the German philosopher was unknown, but that was no barrier as he was run down by a fuel-efficient car in the crossing!
Typical Saturday for me, needed several look ups, but I don‚Äôt mind, and it was an enjoyable solve.

Award for the most interesting clue for BRA. 

I put in CHOCULA and hoped it was right. It made me smile. 

But a lot of this puzzle was hard hard hard. Jay before TOM. Crime before PRINT. Byte before TYPE. 
and so few gimmes. FROM EAR TO EAT was one, S AND M was another.  HYBRID and CAMERA but I didn‚Äôt know what they were paired with. 

I felt like a dummy!!
Have a soapy broey Saturday !  I actually enjoyed this puzzle - proper Saturday challenge imo

I had OH bOY for a while, before realizing Lamar Backson probably wasn't a real person.

Fun puzzle, despite the reference to bridge, which is something I refuse to believe people play outside of Edith Wharton novels.
For me, this one was hard, fun and fair! As one of the commenters noted, just what Saturday mornings were made for.

Being someone who only started this crossword regularly in February, I'm one of the few who beat my average Saturday solve time, though I'm not sure by how much because there are different times showing depending on whether I look at the crossword or the Statistics page. I suspect it has something to do with my internet going down in the middle of the solve.

Some nice wordplay in the clues for TINE, ROE, SUBWAY STSTEM etc. I suspect that I would have listed CHOCULA there too had I lived in a country where that was a known brand.

Phew!üòÆ‚Äçüí® üòÖ That was definitely a Saturday grid. I started this last night and got through 70% of it and just couldn‚Äôt think of anything else that made sense in there. Slept on it. This morning the answers just seemed to fill themselves in. One answer that I knew for certain last night was CHOCULA. We had an Italian exchange student last year and the only thing she would eat for breakfast was Count CHOCULA cereal.  Every. Single. Morning. ü§¢ü§Æ On the other hand, the college baseball pitcher that we hosted for a summer ate Special K with strawberries every single morning and two gallons of milk a week! ü§£ 
I never even considered ore as an answer for smelt as we eat a lot of sushi and ROE popped in right away. Leave NO TRACE was another gimme, and I liked the clever clue. I had BROEs initially, but SOAPY fixed that. BROEY is cringy, IMO. The bottom triple stack was the last to fill for me, and once I finally figured out LAMAR JACKSON, the rest filled out quickly. Took me 13 minutes longer than my average üòÖ That was a worthy workout for my brain, Sam.

I was so stuck on DRACULA being correct. Vampires are ‚Äòout‚Äù (as in, like a light; asleep) for breakfast, right? Worked for me. The children‚Äôs cereal never entered my mind. That kind of stuff was verboten in my childhood home, and in that of my children. Thus, my NE corner was a hot mess for far too long.

Being confident that the mysterious wax collectible was some kind of ‚Ä¶CARD further added to the muck. (I knew the physics measurement had to be PHI or CHI, but what is a LCRECARD?? Ha!) Still eked it out slightly under my Saturday average, but not by much thanks to that stubborn mental block. 

Loved this puzzle with all its fresh fill! Makes me sad that we‚Äôll be back to the easy ones for a few days.
The Dark Lord Of The Spelling Bee delivers a crunchy, chewy Saturday breakfast.  What a good workout!

I'm just here for the Damage Report...I got a good bit of this (cruel, sly, rigged, well-nigh impossible) puzzle, and I have no more time to devote to it.
Talk amongst yourselves while I scroll down to the Answer Key.

Mysteries abound: Why have I heard of Count CHOCULA despite never buying or serving it?  Is an NFL MVP really puzzle-worthy?  Why do all roads lead to IPHONEs?  Is 26D a word?

OH bOY!  That error, along with put on ‚ÄúAN Air‚Äù, knowing the names of only 2 or 3 current NFL players and nothing of ‚ÄúGravity‚Äôs Rainbow‚Äù, and thinking the Formula I divisions must refer to a class of car made the SE very difficult to untangle.

The good use of misdirection and clues having multiple possible legit answers made this a good difficult puzzle. I have a pretty broad knowledge base, but I always expect a few unknowns in a Saturday puzzle. I thought this puzzle might have had one or two too many esoteric or niche answers, but it was borderline. At least most of those (like PETER IV, and LAMAR JACKSON) could be competently guessed at with enough letters. Others like FICHTE and SOLI  required all the crosses.

I had finesse before SLAM BID.  I‚Äôm not sure I would call that a ‚Äútactic‚Äù, but close enough I guess. 

Also thank goodness I grew up in the era of wacky sugared cereals. CHOCULA was a gimme, but I tried rHo before PHI and cOd before ROE, making that section rough as well.
Broey?
Good one. Ore before ROE, Tahiti before TUVALU. Post-puzzle googling assured me that BROEY is a word in use (unfortunately), and that ‚Äúput on AN ACT‚Äù is an idiom and not painted green.
OH JOY-- another proper noun wonderland! not to mention the benefit of knowing French, latin, AND German in order to solve the puzzle.

I know most people here don't have a subscription to the Boston Globe, but just in case some do, here is a fun piece in today's paper. The seven days in the progression of New York Times crosswords though the week, from Monday to Sunday, are described metaphorically as the writer's exes -- a paragraph devoted to each. I think it is fair use to provide an example and I have chosen the Thursday entry... "Thursday ‚Äî what a trickster, that Thursday! Her shenanigans cut both ways. There were days I enjoyed the challenge, as one enjoys an escape room. But sometimes I‚Äôd come home tired from work, only to find her speaking in code. ‚ÄúSweetie,‚Äù I would plead, ‚ÄúCan we just talk normally?‚Äù She‚Äôd respond with a non sequitur question, like, ‚ÄúTwo horses getting married at Walmart?‚Äù The ‚Äúright‚Äù answer had nothing to do with horses. Other days, she‚Äôd dress up in men‚Äôs clothing and pretend not to have legs. What did it even mean? I never knew. Her apartment was a pigsty, but Thursday herself was a fragrant partner, always dabbed with a sweet ester. The paradox encapsulates our time together." https://www.bostonglobe.com/2025/10/11/opinion/love-puzzle-new-york-times/

Fun, fair, and very difficult for me. I believe I may have achieved a ‚Äúpersonal worst‚Äù time for Saturday if I don‚Äôt count falling asleep mid-puzzle. A couple of things amused me. Do you ever have a gimme that you would just as soon you didn‚Äôt know? PTRAP was such a gimme but I could have died happy without ever having had to encounter one under the sink. Then at 42A [Put on ___] one possibility that flitted through my mind, despite the wrong number of letters, was a BRA, leaving me primed for the right answer a couple of rows down.

I sailed through the top 1/3, ambled through the bottom 1/3, and cheated through the midsection (had to look up the philosopher, but once that was in place the rest of the puzzle slowly fell). 

I love Sam's puzzles. I can't remember how I did this but somehow I got a list of his NYT puzzles (along with Robin Weintraub and Joe DiPietro) and printed a whole slew of Friday and Saturday puzzles. They live in my carry-on bag along with 2 pens (because flight attendants don't have spares if you need one). I'm always happily entertained and the time (forgive me) flies by.
Yay! The once a month puzzle that makes me think I might actually get stumped. Thank you. Lots of fun.
CHOCULA and BROEY were actually two of the gimmes for me. Southwest corner has me flummoxed though.

Anyone else sing "The Philosophers Drinking Song" to themselves trying to solve 26D? üòÇ Sadly it didn‚Äôt help here (although it has served me well in other instances!)

Gardening nit: you buy and plant bulbs in the Fall. They come up in the Spring. I guess BULBS could refer to the flower itself but still...

A fun and challenging Saturday! Thanks Sam!

Not so warmy this morning, and not as birdy as yesterday. The water is slightly white-cappy with the wind being more blowy than yesterday.
   I'm picturing George Carlin ranting; ‚ÄúHere is another pack of (string of expletives) who ought to be (something horrible done to them): People who create new adjectives by adding a "y".‚Äù  Or, ‚ÄúPeople who make up words with shortened words.‚Äù Both grievances would be hilarious, sweary, but rad.
   I actually see the former as cute and humorous, but thank goodness it replaced ‚Äú-ish.‚Äù My daughters-in-law make it sound so cute, the ‚Äúy's‚Äù get a pass. I saw ‚Äúfighty‚Äù yesterday, which was grinny.
   The latter? Def not my fav-ish. Too abbreviationy.

P.S. That's one bad-(vulgar for bum) bunny! Very pecy

Hard, eventually doable, filled with some things I don't know, and yet neither fun nor joyful nor even particularly interesting.

So just another Ezersky puzzle I guess.  :(

It was okay.  Proper difficulty level at least.

Now that was a proper Saturday challenge, NE corner had me stymied for a good while and I did eventually cave and google PTRAP to get it going, whIch helped me to finally get the ‚ÄúCount out for breakfast‚Äù.  Or at least I thought, misinterpreting ‚Äúout‚Äù as asleep and putting DRACULA but that was not working with the crossing clues and eventually I finally thought of his tasty doppelg√§nger.

So yeah, good puzzle!

Oh my STARS and garters, that was a proper Saturday slobberknocker. Took me forever to get my head around MASTER SWITCH as a "source of great power," for example. Oh, of course. I was thinking of some kind of breeder reactor. Also, relieved that 7D was not CLAMS. (H/T to Captain Quahog.)
I loved this puzzle! Perfect Saturday!

Canada before TUVALU was one of many problems I had with this fun puzzle.

Also, couldn't think of a five-letter synonym for dentistry to answer Dominatrix's practice.

Fun Fact: The Bra Chain is still intact, the task of disassembly having fallen to a group of men.
Over my average, as are all my attempts at Sam‚Äôs puzzles!

No time to read all the posts, to look for any brouhahas over ohhs or  ahhs or oohs or aahs. But oh boy and oh joy, today I followed my talent for unlucky guesses to the dark places I have never been (i.e. guessing correctly this time) or seen ( an unwatched TV called ARYA (sister of Iron Maiden), and an Ezersky that I didn‚Äôt find moving).

The NYT has its Saturday crossword, the Guardian publishes an uber hard quiz on the same day. Here is today's: https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2025/oct/11/who-founded-the-royal-ballet-school-in-1926-the-saturday-quiz?CMP=Share_AndroidApp_Other I always wonder, are people actually able to solve that? I usually know one or two answers, sometimes less, extremely rarely more. Even though the Guardian features comments, they are never enabled for this quiz so I can't ask there...
Bulbs are not really a spring purchase. They are a spring bloom.
Tough but awesome.

First time I've had to do a search on my answers in a long time--I checked spelling on three of them. That verified what I thought was the most probable choice for two of them, but the third gave me an answer that had not occurred to me. 

So this one gets an asterisk in my streak.

I have to bemoan my saga. I was switching letters in and out of three places. When PETER for the king didn't get the happy music, I tried some other letters for FICH_E. To me, a foothold is not necessarily an instant gimme. It‚Äôs more about a statistical convergence, if you will. Today, for example, I started off reading the down clues first because the spanners across were unlikely to yield early answers. TOM was a gimme, but it didn‚Äôt help with the acrosses. SCROD is usually the 5-letter answer for anything swimming off the coast of New England and WATT was 70-90% likely to be the engineer in question, but neither elucidated the spanners. But then 11D was likely CRADLE, which crossed the likely DEFECT, which crossed the likely FESTIVAL *and* the likely DIET _ _ _. Taken all together, it‚Äô was statistically a sure-fire cluster that broke the puzzle open. 

Pro tip (if I may speak as a pro based on having brushfire-burned my way  through the archives): When you get a clue to which you‚Äôre pretty sure you‚Äôve got a likely answer, first check the crosses that hit its consonants, especially ones that are less common in English. In CRADLE, the D is a pretty common letter, so its crossing DEFECT didn‚Äôt prompt me to fill in both. But the possible DEFECT has an F in it, which instantly prompted FESTIVAL, and that F instantly became a solid ‚Äújoint‚Äù for the two entries. 

I never just go through the clues from A to Z looking for things I know. I look for footholds for crosses as soon as I *think* I know an answer. 

Hope that makes sense. (They served Bloody Mary‚Äôs at brunch‚Ä¶)

@Matt

my husband is a puzzle constructor but almost never solves. he does look at the puzzle every day; he just has zero interest in solving crosswords.

he might be an anomaly, but i imagine there are others like him, where the act of creation and creativity in coming up with the theme and / or building the puzzle is really satisfying, and solving doesn't satisfy that itch.

i think for many of us hobbyists who don't do puzzles full-time as Erik, Will, and Paolo do, there's probably a stronger affinity towards either solving or constructing. i started out as a solver only, but as i've gotten more into constructing, i'm much more interested in constructing than solving. 

don't get me wrong -- i still solve every day, but i do it much more from the perspective of learning about the craft of construction than for anything else.
